values:
1. What did you do in 2009 that you'd never done before?
Became a father, and all things related to that. Believe it or not, I had never given a diaper change before Sophia.

2. Did you keep your new years' resolutions, and will you make more for next year?
My new years resolution for ought nine was to build savings even while having a baby. Yes, I did keep that resolution. The goal is to make 2010 the year we eliminate credit card debts.

3. Did anyone close to you give birth?
Many people did. Seems being pregnant brought an awareness of everyone else who was pregnant. None more special or important than Amanda, though.

4. Did anyone close to you die?.
No.

5. What countries did you visit?
Went to Washington in October… J

6. What would you like to have in 2010 that you lacked in 2009?
That’s tough. I’ve seen so many people in such need this last year. We are very well off by most standards, so this is difficult to think of. I would like to have an HAS account that is building in size, rather than being constantly in debt to myself.

7. What dates from 2009 will remain etched upon your memory, and why?
February 15, and February 28. Sophia’s due date, and her actual birthday. The events of February 28, though… I will never forget that day from waking up early to getting set up in the hospital to watching Flip that House type shows, to Jet arriving/lunch to the long afternoon into the evening, all the visits with doctors, Charm (our good luck charm), the very quick prep for surgery, Sophia’s actual birth, the hours spent in the nursery, the last hour of the day spent in the hospital room with Amanda and Sophia, eating the Subway sandwich Andrew brought.

8. What was your biggest achievement of the year?
Budgeting for, saving for, researching, and purchasing our new computers. I’m very proud of how well I did with that.

9. What was your biggest failure?
There were plenty of little things. Not filling out greeting cards in a timely fashion.

10. Did you suffer illness or injury?
Minor bumps and bruises medically throughout the year. Most notable: swine flu. Honorable mention goes to the dental work I had done in January.

11. What was the best thing you bought?
The computers. Honorable mention to our camcorder.

12. Whose behavior merited celebration?
No one more so than Amanda, who handled the late parts of pregnancy (version, ahem!) and the transition to motherhood wonderfully. Seriously, who works full time and still has the energy and motivation to *make* baby food? I mean it when I say not a day has gone by in which I have not found myself deeper in love with her this year.

13. Whose behavior made you appalled and depressed?
There have been certain co-workers. Some I can talk about here, others I cannot. I’d rather not though. The behaviour has ranged from laziness to lying to cheating to public urination. Not the kinds of things I want to dwell on when I am in such a good place.

14. Where did most of your money go?
Baby-related expenses. If I were to make a guess, probably either formula or diapers. I’d guess diapers.

15. What did you get really, really, really excited about?
Sophia’s birthday. The Shawn Mullins concert. New computers. Watching Sophia on Christmas. Just to name a few.

16. What song will always remind you of 2009?
“Light You Up”, a still-unreleased Shawn Mullins song that he premiered a various concerts this summer -- including the one in the old porno theater in Portland.

17. Compared to this time last year, are you happier?
Yes. Much happier.

18. What do you wish you'd done more of?
Journal, take Sophia videos, document Sophia’s first year. I’d give us a B- in that category.

19. What do you wish you'd done less of?
Make the bed. I was struggling for something to write until Amanda asked me to make it.. J

20. How will you be spending Christmas?
Went to church at 8 instead of midnight. Had a traditional breakfast, opened presents as a family and then went up to Newberg to see Grandma, Grandpa, and Uncle Corey.

21. Who did you spend the most time on the phone with?
Probably my mom.

22. Did you find new love in 2009?
Oh yes. Every day. My newest love, of course, was and continues to be Sophia.

23. How many one-night stands?
Many, many, many. Amanda took more than her share of the midnight feedings. But looking back, I understand the talk about midnight feedings. All I can remember from March and April, really, is getting up to feed Sophia at 4 am and watching Seinfeld. Honorable mention goes to January (weird sleep habits thanks to painkillers) and October/early November (even weirder sleep habits thanks to being high on prednisone).

24. What was your favorite TV program?
Seinfeld. Would have gone nuts without the complete series, most of which I watched in Sophia’s first couple of months. Couple of honorable mentions: Big Brother (of course), Desperate Housewives (thanks to swine flu), Friends (January/jello/late nights), American Idol, Fox News at 10, Intervention…

25. Do you hate anyone now that you didn't hate this time last year?
No.

26. What was the best book you read?
Kevin Nealon’s fatherhood book. I had no idea, but he’s a funny guy.

27. What was your greatest musical discovery?
Adam Lambert.

28. What did you want and get?
A healthy daughter. As I put it five years ago, an endless stock of razor blades and contact lenses. A camcorder. Computers. A chance to take the back way from Newberg up to 217, which I hadn’t done in years.

29. What did you want and not get?
Have I mentioned how spoiled we were this year? I want a manager position. I want to be paid enough that Amanda can go part time or full time stay at home mom. We’re still working at that.

30. What was your favorite film of this year?
UP. Great movie, and one that I can watch again and again. I had no idea when I sat down to watch that it would be so powerful.

31. What did you do on your birthday, and how old were you?
I don’t remember the answer to either question. ;)

32. What one thing would have made your year immeasurably more satisfying?
Learning how to skip.

33. How would you describe your personal fashion concept in 2009?
Gangbanger.

34. What kept you sane?
Amanda. Honorable mention to Seinfeld, and certainly to the baby swing. I relied on that swing more than Amanda, methinks.

35. Which celebrity/public figure did you fancy the most?
For a brief while, Jon and Kate. Then I got very sick of them. I’d rather fancy Shawn Mullins any day of the week.

36. What political issue stirred you the most?
A three way tie: health care, unemployment,  and the potentially fudged numbers at Strategic Vision.

37. Who did you miss?
Old friends.

38. Who was the best new person you met?
Sophia J

39. Tell us a valuable life lesson you learned in 2009:
I am good enough. Really, though, spending any time with Sophia reminds me that although I know I’m nothing special, to her I am DAD. And so in her eyes, I am good enough. Profound, ¿no?

40. Quote a song lyric that sums up your year:
Now you are the burden/Of my generation/But I sure do love you/Let’s get that straight.

-or-

It just keeps pouring out/Like juice from berries on the vine….

Sophia is growing so fast. I am already becoming the stereotypical parent, saying that I want to write things down so I remember but yet time is going to fast to leave me time to think about milestones, etc. Some milestones that come to mind. *She has very recently learned how to blow raspberries. Little is as fun for her as laying on the couch (or floor) with me and blowing raspberries back and forth. Messy, disgusting sounding, and not at all lady-like, but very fun. Also very fun for me to get to see and hear her reactions when I play back. Of course, it's always fun to watch her reactions to things... but especially when she is amused. *She has been giggling for quite some time now (started in late March or early April? see - that's why I should be keeping notes). But just today she had the biggest belly laugh that I've seen. You know, the kind where you almost choke you are laughing so hard. Oh, that was great. *Since birth, she has been very strong. For instance, by three weeks she was demonstrating amazing head control when we held her. By six weeks, she was bearing some weight on her legs when we held her on our laps. Now she's pushing her torso up when on her stomach. We lay her down in the center of her crib on her belly to sleep, and she will wake up in the corner of the crib on her back. So I know she's been flipping over to a certain degree for a while, but today we were laying on the quilt playing with Barky (her first real toy, a little blue stuffed dog that barks) and she rolled herself from her back to her belly. Wow. And she's getting to the point that I hold her hands and she stomps her feet in an attempt to "walk" forward. She just wants to be mobile so badly - it is a little frustrating for her that she cannot move, but that's part of being a baby. *Although she can't crawl, she has started the process of "creeping". It's still very primitive but exciting nonetheless. *Speaking of things that have started, teething. She's grouchier now than when she was younger and I attribute it to gum pain. I feel bad for her, but what are you going to do? Of course, when she is distracted from the discomfort, she's a blast. *Amanda has gotten me into the habit of watching Sesame Street with Sophia on my mornings off - may not have been intentional but that's the way it has gone down. I feel old saying it, but it's just not like I remember it "back in my day". Amanda described it best by saying something to the effect that it used to be 60% Mr. Rogers/feelings show, 40% learning show whereas now it is much more a learning show, and much less a feelings show. And although it is by no means bad (I do look forward to watching it with Sophia when she is old enough to understand it), it's very different, and I miss the old days. *Just have to say that I am very excited to be watching Shawn Mullins at the Aladdin in Portland next Tuesday. *Work is still work. I still feel every bit as passionate about my job but it takes a major backseat to the real priorities. *Amanda did it very well and I will use her words to help me relive the birth or the version. No more words on those from me. After all, my baby is awake, and although I have taken time to feed her between bullets on this post, it is time to spend some time with her. Maybe tonight I will upload another video or two to my YouTube account.

After 8 long years of GWB.... finally, finally, finally. It was every bit as much an electoral landslide as predicted. Still, I was nervous. And now to know without any doubt, by 11 pm eastern, that we have a new leader in President Elect Obama... how wonderful. And to know that we won't wake up tomorrow to see that the entire thing has changed a la 2000... this is all so great. Watching McCain's concession speech and Obama's victory speech... you could get a real feel for how important this day is. I'm very tired now and going to bed. But this is bigger than I'd ever imagined.

My goodness, today was a fun day. The it that I referred to yesterday.. the feeling of impending busy-ness... it was back with a vengeance today. Granted, it didn't last all day, and it didn't even result in any big sales. But from 10-4 I was in constant demand. More often than not there were 2 or 3 people waiting to be helped. The department was crowded in a way that it hasn't been since... well, I can't recall a single time I've seen South Salem so crowded. Add to that the fact that we now have all but only one of our major six-hour items in store, and I'm getting pumped. Now begins my favorite two months of the year. The careful receiving of stock, the careful planning for Black Friday, the execution of the plans, the sales, the business... it never gets old for me. This is why I love my work. This is what I look forward to during the dreadfully slow summer months. It's exhausting. Oftentimes it becomes irritating. But I enjoy every moment of it. (And did I mention we are down to the final phase of receiving our six-hour merchandise... already? How awesome. Three full weeks of planning and executing without the need to worry about the "did we gets") To continue with my recent obsession over gas mileage/prices --- someone was recently telling me how by driving at 63 mph they were able to get much better mileage than they used to at 70mph. So I decided to try it over the last week. It added about a minute to my commute (oh my, a whole minute!) but I got 35.7 miles to the gallon over the week. Compare that with my previous best of 33.99mpg, and my average of 32.4mpg in the Nissan, and I'm impressed. Granted, one 300 mile tank could easily represent a statistical outlier when compared with over 5 months and 10,000 miles of data. But the point remains that for one extra minute I could potentially boost my gas mileage. It's worth further investigation to see if this was a fluke. Fluke or not, how about those gas prices? Less than four months ago, I paid $4.20/gal. 357 miles cost me $47.15 --- 13.2 cents per mile. Today, I paid $2.14/gal. 309 miles cost me $18.55. The last time I had a stop at the gas station cost less than $20? I can't recall, honestly. It hasn't happened since I started judiciously tracking mileage in May, that much is for certain. The really impressive stat today is the cost per mile... 5.9cents. There's plenty of talk that after the election on Tuesday, gas prices will stabilize or start increasing. I certainly hope not. But if they do, oh well. I am just thrilled with how low they have come. 25 weeks. 15 weeks left til February 15th. Depending on the perspective that could be a long time or not long at all. Putting it into some sort of perspective... fifteen weeks ago was July 19th. Nothing memorable to attribute to that date. But the biggest memory I have from July was the BBQ at my parents' house for my Aunt Sheila. I left work early that day... after setting Back to School in SOD, it was very sunny and hot on the drive home... Amanda skipped work the next day to stay up late and watch Big Brother with my parents (I had the next day off)... that feels like just yesterday, and it has been over 15 weeks already. I can only wonder... on February the 15th, will I look back on today, as a dad, and wonder where the time went? So many people have been buying baby clothes for us left and right. All of it is so adorable. And our daughter will be wearing these clothes next year. How crazy is that?!? There are times when I'm still trying to wrap my mind around the reality of the situation. And yet, by Thanksgiving, we'll have hit the beginning of the third trimester. I am beginning to doubt I'll have time to get my head fully wrapped around the situation before the situation is fully upon us. It's great! :) Time for bed. Must take advantage of the extra hour of rest tonight.

On the way to work, I saw six pumpkins lined up in front of someone's house. They spelled O-B-A-M-A and the sixth one had the Obama logo. What a cool idea. Work was quite busy today. And I felt.... it. The precursor to true busy-ness. The feeling in the air that people are starting to - or about to start - spending money. That's a great feeling. Exhilirating, really. I haven't had the chance to move with that sense of urgency since back to college at Corvallis, and even then it was not a real sense of urgency as it was not my store... I was just helping. This was a real sense of urgency. It was great. Sold two 52" Samsung TVs, one right after the other. The second of which was sold to Darin Baker. Pretty fun. $4,000 in two transactions. Granted, in four short weeks, that sort of money in a short timeline will not be a big deal. But today, it is. That's about all that there is for today. I had a blast with it, but I don't have much more to say about it.

Just a couple of random thoughts from the day today. *I'm ready for next Tuesday to be here and gone. Not that I haven't loved watching polling data change and comparing statistics from 2004 and 2008 (and one day looking all the way back to the 1868 election for some real historical perspective... and yes, I've loved FiveThirtyEight.com ... BUT we got at least half a dozen fliers in the mail today. Mostly vote Merkley, vote Smith, vote Merkley, vote Smith, vote Smith, vote Merkley Merkley Merkley Smith.... and a couple making fun of how ugly Bill Sizemore is and how his measures are terrible yadda yadda yadda (minus the sex)... Anyhow. I will say that it's really fascinating to watch the difference in state-by-state voting between the 1928 and 1932 elections. How cool is that! *I most certainly will be working Thanksgiving day. I take that as very good news. The other half of that is that I will not be having to close a dozen times in the six weeks of the retail holiday season. Sure, I may have to close a couple of times. But not twice a week. So that's good. And honestly, I enjoy working Thanksgiving. I'm good at it, and it makes me more comfortable and confident with the level of preparation on Black Friday. *Miami vs Denver on Sunday will be televised. And I'm off. How exciting. Very much so, thank you. I think that's it for today. More some other time.

Far too much drama today. It's quickly gotten late so no story time. I had on the tour today for every person to take one SD card and get 5-6 pictures around the store for use in our display digital picture frames. There were 5 frames needing pictures, 5 people working. Each person filled one frame. Very simple task. Daniel refused. I mean... flat out refused to do as asked. I have never had an employee refuse to do as asked before. First time for everything, but for something so... stupid? Ridiculous. After far too much back-and-forth and second chances, the conversation got to the point of me confirming that I had asked him to do it, he refused, had told him to do it, and that he was still refusing. So I gave him an ultimatum - take the pictures, or I would send him home. He called my bluff and said something along the lines of "I guess I'm going home then". I let him know that as a result of his actions, I would be following up with Dave and disciplinary action would be taken. I think that's the point he realised I was dead serious. He reconsidered, and took the pictures. After getting back from taking his photos, he apologized for his actions. I told him several times throughout the day... I know full well that taking 5-6 pictures is a small task. And I know that anyone could do it. I'm sure that I could have just had someone else take his pictures for him. But as I told him - that would be missing the whole point. The principle of the thing. That I am the manager here - and as such I will not tolerate an employee refusing to do as asked. It felt good to stand up for myself, but it was the most painfully awkward interaction that I can remember in quite some time. Every other thing about the day was great. As smooth and happily productive as could be. I'll note that I even had a great conversation with Bendina over lunch. I made a comment about providence ... very casual, in my best attempt to not be preachy. Hearing my comment, Bendina's eyes lit up. She was taken off guard by me saying that. She was touched, though. Her reaction had an impact on me. Every day working around her has been a different experience. I have done my best to not walk on eggshells around her. It's very difficult... I want to avoid the topic of her boys, of anything relating to death. But she brings the topics up ................... I am honored, humbled, touched that Marcia specifically wants Bendina at SS through 1/4/09 and then at CV because, as she has told me several times now, there's no better combination to work with Bendina than Rich and me.  I'm just trying to live up to those expectations. I don't feel qualified to help Bendina with her grief. But... if my faith can help, hmm. I wasn't able to directly help or be present during the funeral, yard sale.. all the times that Bendina was surrounded. This is the challenge I have been given. Maybe I'm not qualified to help with the grief, but this is my chance to "be there"...  How cathartic. No story time but just as verbose as if I would have given story time....

News on the work front. As of January 4th, I will be going back to Corvallis. Jose will be going to South Salem. Bendina is staying at SS until January 4th, and then coming to CV with me. Although I've been apprehensive about the idea of going back to Corvallis --- I know that it's an uphill battle and one in which I will not have a particularly supportive manager above me --- I am very happy about this news. Some reasons.. *I get to see Amanda at work, every day. I really have missed that. *Gas. It's an 8 mile round trip commute working at Corvallis. Multiplied by five days a week and by two people (me and Amanda), that's 80 miles per week driven for commute. Compare that to the 80 mile one way commute to and from Salem. A week's worth of total household driving equates to one day of driving at my current location. If gas stays at this price, It'll cost around $7 a week to drive to work. Right now, I'm around $35 per week. That's a $28 weekly savings, make that $100 a month that I'll save on gas. More savings if gas increases. Of course, I would be fine if it keeps going down... less savings but less overall cost! *Time. Right now if I work 7-5, I'm home around 6pm. After 1/4, I'll be getting home around 5:15pm. I get my evenings back with a vengeance! Not to mention that my days usually last 12 hours from leaving home to getting home. Come January... 10 1/2 hours, tops. Talk about adding an extra hour and a half to my day! On the other end of the day, come January I can wake up at 6 am for a 7 am shift and have time to very leisurely get ready for work. Nowadays, by 6 am I need to be finishing up and out the door by 6:10 am. Extra sleep! *Chance to continue to prove myself to Marcia. She's made it clear that she expects good things. She wants the department clean and she no longer wants to walk in and see watter bottles and miscellaneous crap behind the counter. *Bringing Bendina over the same day I come. First... I don't think it would be wise to send Bendina back to the same environment as she came from. Being in a new environment she can have something of a fresh start. She can create an identity for herself that does not involve the boys centrally like her identity did at Albany. That isn't to say that they shouldn't play a part in who she is - they always will as that grief will stay with her for the rest of her life, certainly - but knowing her and seeing her progress since working with me, I think it is fair to say that in work terms, some new scenery will do her good. ---> Not to mention that (a) keeping her at SS through Christmas will give me 6 extra weeks to prepare her for Corvallis, to teach her, to get her primed, to essentially turn her into my assistant - which is how I fully intend to use her and (b) bringing her over will make my transition easier. The toughest part of a new location is getting the department on the same page. On my page. Well, I'll have one key employee already on my page. ----> On top of that, the timing will work out well. We will have a month and a half or so to work together on the top level most visible problems, and to get started on the maintenance problems. Then she will have time to maintain the department while I'm on leave (great development time for her), and then I'll get back and we'll have the department polished and shining by the end of the school year. By that point, it'll be time to start planning for a new BTS/BTC season, and with two steady hands I think we can do quite well. But that's getting a bit ahead of myself. For now, let it be simplified that I'm excited with the direction that we're going. There are plenty of more reasons that I'm excited about this, that for the sake of brevity (haha, when have I been known to be brief) I've omitted.

Driving home today, having just gotten on to Philomath Blvd, 2 police cars came screaming down the street behind me. Both of them were sirens blazing, all lights on, moving fast to wherever they were going. I think they were actually state troopers, but it was dark and they were going fast.. I didn't catch it. The funny part is that Meredith Brooks' song "My Little Town" had just started on my iPod as the police approached.

[backstory] ... Remember Meredith Brooks? She sang "Bitch" back in the mid-90s. Good song, cool video in which she floats around in a spinning room. Anyway. On the same album, she sings about how she spent her youth in her little town, wanting to get away to the big city. Now she just wants to get back to the peace and quiet. Her little town was Corvallis. How about that. And it's true... Corvallis is a peaceful town. The worst thing that happens here is college kids getting drunk on the weekends. But (especially when the kids are gone for the summer!) it's a quiet, peaceful town. Nice place to live. Safe. [/backstory] ... So as her tribute to the peaceful town (Corvallis) begins, two cops come roaring down the street. I cracked up.

In other news... I got to deal with some drama at work today. I think one of my employees is having something of a breakdown. He didn't show up for his shift today. I couldn't get a hold of him. He called about an hour past his shift's start time, and when I asked if he was okay, he told me "I guess". When I asked if he knew he was scheduled, he did. He "didn't know" if he was going to come in. Just an eery, cold, quiet tone. He decided to come in, but by that point I was pretty well freaked out. For someone who is normally jovial, talkative, outgoing, friendly... to act like this... it reminds me somewhat of Terrence's breakdown at Corvallis two years ago. I don't much care for the position I was put in - talking him in to coming in to work... asking him what he wanted me to do... very awkward position. Very awkward phone call. Not one I would care to repeat any time soon.

Other than that though... pretty good day at work. Oh... and in the life of gas purchasing...paid $2.719/gallon today. Get this.. that is down 50 cents in 17 days... 29 cents in ten days... 21 cents in five days.. One month ago I was thrilled to pay $3.38. Considering that just over 3 months ago I paid $4.20... $2.72 does not look bad at all. Granted, this does include a 10 cent rewards discount and an additional 10 cent employee discount... so a regular customer would have paid $2.92. Still.. no complaints from me!

[edit] At $24.72, that was the cheapest fillup I have had for the Nissan since purchasing it in May. The scary part... I have had 6 fillups with fewer miles than today. My July 14th fillup gave me 294 miles (versus 295 today).. and cost $39.01... $14 more for one mile less. How crazy. Love these sinking gas prices! And love documenting what I've spent so I can look back on it and track it..... [/edit]

Let the record show... I do not much care for MNF games between the Broncos and the Patriots. It's true that over the past 10+ years, the Broncos have owned the Patriots in regular games. Something like 8-3 under Mike Shanahan against the Patriots. One of those three losses came five years ago in a Monday night heartbreaker. And then there's tonight's 41-7 loss. Just plain despicable. 4-3 isn't a bad record for this point in the season, and it's still good enough for a one game division lead. At least their schedule for the rest of the season is looking slightly easier than that of the San Diego Chargers - the only other team that has any real shot at the division. Anyway... I have 13 days to mull over this loss and hope that the Broncos can come back and win against Miami to make it 5-3 instead of 4-4... In other fun... during the commercials I got to enjoy Comcast Sports Net showing the May 31, 1990 game between the Portland Trail Blazers and Phoenix Suns... game 6 of the Western Conference Championships. Portland won the game 112-109. While I was dejected watching the Broncos fall apart, I actually found myself cheering for the Blazers. I actually clapped on a couple of great Clyde "The Glide" Drexler steals and one great Drexler dunk. I have vague recollections of those years of basketball... all of the names were familiar to me. But really, I was too young to admire how great those Blazers were. It's a wonder that they didn't win any championships. But then again, they were playing against Magic Johnson/Joe Dumars and of course later Michael Jordan in the finals during the early 90s. Do I remember watching a couple of those games at Aunt Sheila & Uncle Bob's place? Maybe it was the finals against the Pistons. But I could swear there was at least one game that I watched there between the Blazers and Suns. Anyway. Isn't it amazing how after 18 years watching those teams can still be that much fun, and I could get so into it? I think so. At least I got to watch one team win. Even if it was 18 years ago!

Well it's been too long. And any time I go months without updating, I have a hard time thinking of where to start up again. Several times over the last couple of months I have wanted to update... just to mention little things along the way that have now left my mind. But the idea of updating is so daunting when faced with months of events left unmentioned. July was a quiet month around here. Mostly just a month spent working and trying to avoid the heat. Then again, it wasn't terribly hot this year. There were a couple of days above 100 degrees but really, the worst heat wave of the year was around the time of our honeymoon. By the time July hit, the worst hot weather of the year had passed. August was more memorable. I spent a lot of time at work. Dave took most of the month off, which left me in charge. That was great. The way the schedule worked out, though... I worked two 6 day weeks. Great paychecks but long weeks. Many hours spent on the NFL TV display. Out of 50 hours worked that particular week... probably about 20-25 hours on that display. Exhausting. Saw two concerts in August. Prior to that, had only seen one (big) concert. ---- I don't count any of the fairs that I have seen concerts at... they just don't count ---....... Pat Benatar was on the hottest day of summer proper. Easily 105 degrees at 7 pm when the concert started. Her opener wasn't exciting but she and her husband are quite good. I hadn't realized before that day but that woman can belt it and she has some really great songs that I was completely unaware of prior to the concert. Wasn't even one I would have ordinarily gone to but it was a going away gift from the folks at Albany (based on the inside joke that apparently Pat Benatar is my mother). Great gift. ALSO went to the Oregon Zoo for the Avett (pronounced Ay-vet) Brothers concert. They are very energetic on stage! ... or so we are told. The opening act for the Avett Brothers was Shawn Mullins... and of course he is the reason we went up to the Zoo. Fun fact: it was pouring rain through the whole concert. We spent the whole show (except for his first song, "Twin Rocks, Oregon") practically within arms reach of the stage getting drenched, rocking out. He was "just" an opener, but let's be honest, he was much better than the Avett Brothers. We stuck around for the first 30 seconds or so of there set. Then the lead singer opened his mouth, and we left. They were terrible. But he was worth every penny spent that day. Absolutely wonderful. And his set lasted a full hour. I'm afraid not many people even know who he is. And that's a shame, because he tells the best stories with his music. Anyway... enough about that, I think, for now. September was busy, but not quite as busy as August. Had I spent time writing about little things throughout the month I would have chronicled my adventures in Albany. Turns out that department has fallen apart since I left. One bad thing has happened after another (the most tragic being the LOA that Bendina went on after the loss of her ex-husband and two young sons)... but ultimately, the department has been so badly mismanaged that the stockroom and salesfloor alike are in a shambles. Basic maintenance has not been performed in a matter of months, and it shows.
